Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: An overview of the Planning process
I learned a lot of detailed info about my specific project topic, and the guest speakers gave a great range of information on planning and land use issues more broadly.
I learned a lot about the different jobs around planing and at a high level the skills needed to thrive in those positions.

A great dive into land use topics - a great variety from renewable energy to research municipal code - all very useful! It was a great opportunity to work closely on a land use project on a flexible schedule.

Working with a client was very helpful. I had to manage my time carefully, have open lines of communication with the client, and constantly check in about the format of the project to make sure I was fulfilling the requirements/needs the client had. The guest lecturers were not all very useful to me in particular but I would say at least half directly contributed a skill I would utilize in the future. Hearing from practitioners teaches students in a way a textbook cant' because it shows the real life application of something. That is in valuable.
The lectures on finding zoning information, and analyzing census data were very useful, but perhaps a class exercise around using these tools would have been effective as well.
na

I learned the history and process of land use decision-making at the state and local level, with focus on the legal framework for decisions and contestations.  I gained skills in finding and deciphering land use law for specific regions.
Everything related to land use! Jessica focuses on learning the skills students will need later in land use related careers. Very helpful!
Municipal code use, zoning guideline development
Skills specifically relevant for conducting community engagement work.
Understanding of land use planning tools in my specific area of interest.

Jessica brought in a great bunch of speakers to discuss different land use components, I learned a lot from them. From my conversations with other students it seemed like the projects were pretty hit or miss. Unfortunately mine was a bit of a dud.
It covered a wider range of topics than I expected.
It aligned well with my expectations.
Perfectly!
Pretty well aligned. The class was pretty much what I thought it would be.

I was a little disappointed by my client-- it turned out the project I signed on to do had already been done by another student in 2014. I only discovered this after driving 2.5 hours to visit my client. They didn't have a clear project for me to complete, and I had to come up with something on my own, which is not what I was expecting. Jessica was helpful with coming up with a good project that was interesting to me.
This class met my expectations.
Very well!

Mixed feelings about this. The focus is largely urban but this is a capstone for even natural resource track students specializing in sustainable land management. Would highly recommend two land use clinics tackling urban and non-urban interests.
Perfectly.
Very well
I definitely increased my knowledge of land use issues, and felt like this course built well off of the other land use classes I took at FES.
Because the topics are so broad, I was only able to digest the knowledge from the areas I was most comfortable with.

A lot of FES classes bring in regular guest speakers, but Jessica had really GREAT speakers each week. They were actually engaging at speaking/presenting, had useful things to share, and even though the class was a series of guest lectures, it still felt cohesive. I think it would've been nice to have a day or two where we spent the class discussing and debriefing without a guest, but that's all I would change.
I think the guest speakers are great but maybe there could be more discussion.
Great guest speakers, and great organization. Plenty of support and flexibility to work on projects of your choice. Loved all parts of this class!

Strengths: wide variety of projects to choose from so it caters to basically all types of students. Jessica is a great instructor. Field trips was useful and insightful. 

Weaknesses: the speakers were not all the best (content-wise and engagement-wise) but it could be a product of my personal interest.

The guest lecture format is good for keeping class interesting and engaging. It helps show how varied the potential field of work is and exposes many people from outside the university to students. The once weekly class meetings felt a little short. Perhaps a longer class or two classes per week would better facilitate lectures with longer discussions afterwards or time for other class exercises.

I imagine if you have a great client this class is great. However, if you have a bad client there's no compensating for that. Make sure clients are engaged with clear project goals for the students? I also found the classes completely boring and unhelpful.

One strength of the course is its variety of different presenters who provide a varied picture of land use decisions in practice, but I would say that the same component is also a hindrance to the course.  There were certainly some days in which the topic was so specific (renewable energy siting, etc.) that it felt less applicable to me.  I wonder too if the course could incorporate more specific readings for homework throughout the semester, to keep an ideological flow throughout the course and ensure that students leave with more than just a cursory understanding of various disjointed land use topics.

I very much appreciated the open-ended nature of the final projects, and how available Jessica was to work with students throughout the process.   That level of commitment and individualization makes every project useful for students in their professional growth.
This is a great course. I have no suggestions for improvement.
Predominantly focused on urban issues. Needs more non-urban focus perhaps through a sister land use clinic course.

Strengths is the freedom to conduct a project of your choosing and the regular check-ins provided by Jessica. Weakness is that some of the lectures don't always feel super relevant or necessary, depending on one's project.

We had a lot of really interesting guest speakers that would have been great to have lunch with, like some other courses I've had were structured. The course was also a great time slot (ended at 11:50am) to allow for lunches.

Unfortunately my project wasn't great for this course, so the strengths for me were the speakers (who were generally great and covered a lot of ground!). I understand that there are always going to be some projects that don't work out that well so no hard feelings there, but I would have appreciated the projects getting started earlier in the semester (if felt like we were a month into school before I was able to start on mine). It also would have been nice to touch base about student projects with other students before the last class presentations, I didn't know what many others were working on until then. 

I also didn't feel like the field trip to Stamford was worth the time. I'm sure the chilly, wet weather and transit issue made it worse, but I learned very little and it was almost 4 hours of my day at a busy time in April.
I wish my project had been more focused and better structured - my original client/supervisor was very busy and had to bail out in March.
Highly recommend this as a course or capstone if you're interested or planning to work in the land use and urban planning field.
If you can get a project you like (and you probably can, Jessica is really flexible and wants to make sure everyone has a project they'll benefit from) then it's absolutely worth it.
If you are interested in a project, go for it!
This is a wonderful capstone course! Low time requirements - you have flexibility to work on your project on your own time. Weekly lecturers are very helpful and have great guest lecturers.
Take it and make sure you choose a project that you like as that will be the major source of work for this course.

Participate in class and meet with the professor as much as you can to get the most out of the course. You need to be a proactive student to get the most out of the class, but the resources are there if you seek them out.
Do some due diligence before term and make sure you have an interesting, clearly defined project set up.
If the syllabus and projects listed are of interest to you, take the course!  What you get out of this course definitely hinges on how much effort you put into it.

This is a great way to get hands on experience with towns or other clients. I have referenced my project for this class in several job interviews and it has definitely benefited me to have this experience.
Take it if your interest is in urban land use issues.
Great if you have a project you're excited about.
Choose a project you're very passionate about, but be flexible if the project does not go as planned and you need to switch

Make sure there's a project that really interests you before deciding to take the course, since most of the course is project-based. Also be prepared to do a project solo (if you're a procrastinator this course might not be a great fit).
Pick a project that really interest you and one you are willing to spend quality time and efforts on.
